metadata.titleEn: Surface PAR, SSR and NR products over the Heihe River basin (2012)
metadata.description: We produced surface photosynthetic effective radiation (PAR), solar radiation (SSR) and net radiation (NR) products with 1KM resolution in the heihe basin in 2012.The temporal resolution ranges from instantaneous to hourly and daily.Day-by-day ancillary data were also produced, including aerosol optical thickness, moisture content, NDVI, snow cover, and surface albedo.Among them, PAR and SSR use the method of lookup table to directly invert by combining the stationary weather satellite and polar orbit satellite MODIS product.NR was calculated by analyzing the relationship between net short-wave and net surface radiation.Hourly instantaneous products are weighted by average and integral to obtain hourly and daily cumulative products.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: the data is stored in a grid HDF format, stored in daily folders (such as 2012001), the file is divided into DlySRC, HurSRC, InsSRC, file name "InsSRC.yyyyddd.hhhh.hdf", where yyyy represents the year, DDD represents the date, HHHH represents when, such as inssrc.2012002.0030.hdfRepresents the second day of 2012 solar radiation and net radiation products.
Data reading method: Arcgis, Qgis and other remote sensing software as well as HDF program code and HDF professional software can be used to open and read.Raster images are generated after reading.

background: Monitoring surface radiation budget by remote sensing technique is a very important use of satellite data. Especially for surface solar radiation (SSR), the earliest studies can date back to the 60s of the last century (Fritz, Rao, & Weinstein, 1964). Besides large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage, another main advantage of the satellite remote sensing technique over other approaches (e.g., discrete surface observation or reanalysis modelled products) is that it can accurately capture the spatial distributions and dynamic changes of cloud, which is regarded as a superior modulator of SSR (Forman & Margulis, 2009). Up to now, over decades of rapid development, estimation of SSR based on satellite remote sensing technique has become increasingly mature, and many products have already been produced (Liang, Wang, Zhang, & Wild, 2010; Pinker & Laszlo, 1992; Pinker et al., 2003; Posselt, Mueller, Stockli, & Trentmann, 2012; Zhang, Liang, Zhou, Wu, & Zhao, 2014; Zhang, Rossow, Lacis, Oinas, & Mishchenko, 2004).
research objective: In this paper, we will investigate and quantify the representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based measurements using the surface flux-observation matrix from HiWATER (Li et al., 2013) and the solar radiation data retrieved from geostationary meteorological satellite (Huang, Li, Ma, & Li, 2016).
challenges: Questions such as, how large is the representativeness error of surface measurements in the validation and how much of the product-measurement difference can be attributed to their inherent differing spatial scales, cast doubts on the suitability of this direct validation approach. The current study demonstrates that wildly fluctuating representativeness errors exist which are strongly contingent on the time and space scales of remote sensing products, as well as instant atmospheric conditions. The errors caused by the poor representativeness of surface sites, likely significantly contribute to the large differences between measurements and products.
methods: In this study, the MSD is the variance of representativeness error in time-space domain, which measures the overall variability of representativeness error. During the matrix experiment, all measurements were carried out carefully with continuous supervision. Spirit levels and glass domes of the 17 radiometers were checked weekly to guard against any perceptible instrument tilting and possible soiling of the sensors. A thermal offset correction, a calibration correction, a leveling correction and a correction on soiling error were initially devised to perform in order. The recording cycle of raw SSR was 10 min, and data gaps nearly did not exist during the experiment. The corrected data at the 16 sites would be utilized for the following analyses. Representativeness error of point-scale measurements with respect to grid-level surrounding include two levels of errors, namely detailed error from point to kilometer scales and macroscopic error from kilometer to grid scales.
dataset: As mentioned earlier, surface observation data in this study are only provided by the surface flux-observation matrix from HiWATER-MUSOEXE. This observation matrix includes 17 sets of eddy covariance (EC) system and automatic meteorological station and 4 pairs of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) systems, and covers approximately 5 × 5 km2 spatial area located in the midstream area of Heihe river basin, northwest China. Previous SSR satellite products over Heihe river basin in northwest China are used in the current study. The original spatial resolution of the products is 0.05° (~5 km), and the temporal resolution is half hour.
findings: For an area of 5 × 5 km², 1.4~8.1% of representativeness errors are found from monthly to “instantaneous” timescales; while for an area of 1° × 1° grid, 3.1~8.1% of representativeness errors are seen. On timescales longer than or equal to one day, representativeness errors do not need to be considered for validations of kilometer-level products, but on shorter timescales representativeness errors will affect the validation results to some extent. For instantaneous products with 5 km resolution, our study indicates over 13% of errors can be attributed to the inherent representativeness error, and 30-minute surface measurements are recommended for a routine validation. However, for validations of grid-level products, representativeness errors basically cannot be neglected regardless of timescales.

Definition.Question: What does 'representativeness error' mean in the context of surface radiation data collection?
Definition.Answer: Representativeness error refers to the discrepancy between point-scale ground-based measurements and grid-level satellite products due to differences in spatial scales and atmospheric conditions. It significantly affects the validation of remote sensing products, especially when surface sites poorly represent larger surrounding areas.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'surface flux-observation matrix' in the context of data collection for radiation budget studies?
Definition.Answer: A surface flux-observation matrix refers to a systematic arrangement of multiple measurement systems, such as eddy covariance systems and large aperture scintillometers, deployed across a spatial area to collect comprehensive data on surface fluxes and meteorological parameters for radiation budget studies.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of retrieving solar radiation data from geostationary meteorological satellites compare with using point-scale ground-based measurements in terms of accuracy and spatial coverage?
Comparison.Answer: Retrieving solar radiation data from geostationary meteorological satellites offers large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage and can accurately capture spatial distributions and dynamic changes in cloud cover. In contrast, point-scale ground-based measurements may suffer from representativeness errors due to their limited spatial scales, affecting their accuracy compared to satellite-derived data.

Comparison.Question: In terms of methodological rigor, how does the correction process for ground-based solar radiation measurements compare to the data inversion process using satellite products?
Comparison.Answer: The correction process for ground-based solar radiation measurements involves addressing thermal offset, calibration, leveling, and soiling errors to ensure data accuracy. In contrast, the data inversion process using satellite products relies on combining data from geostationary and polar-orbiting satellites and employing lookup tables to directly retrieve parameters like solar radiation, which involves analyzing relationships between surface radiation components.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of satellite remote sensing techniques improve the accuracy of data collection for surface solar radiation when compared to traditional ground-based measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques can capture spatial distributions and dynamic changes of clouds, which are superior modulators of surface solar radiation. This allows for accurate estimation over large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage, overcoming the limitations of discrete surface observations.

Interpretation.Question: What are the inherent challenges in validating remote sensing products with ground-based measurements, and how can these challenges impact the interpretation of data patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges include representativeness errors due to differing spatial scales between ground-based measurements and remote sensing products. These errors can significantly impact validation, as the poor representativeness of surface sites may contribute to large differences, thus affecting interpretation of data patterns.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the representativeness errors in point-scale measurements be quantified and mitigated to ensure robust data collection in studies involving surface flux observations?
Interpretation.Answer: Representativeness errors can be quantified by measuring the variance of errors in time-space domains. Mitigation strategies include careful supervision of measurements, regular calibration, and correction of potential errors such as thermal offsets and soiling. Additionally, using a matrix of multiple measurement sites can help understand and reduce these errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes representativeness errors in surface solar radiation data when validating remote sensing products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Representativeness errors are caused by the different spatial scales of remote sensing products and point-scale ground-based measurements, and are strongly influenced by time and space scales as well as atmospheric conditions. The poor representativeness of surface sites contributes significantly to the large differences between measurements and products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might surface observation data collection be challenging for accurately validating satellite-derived solar radiation products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Surface observation data collection can be challenging due to the need for continuous supervision and various corrections, such as thermal offset, calibration, leveling, and soiling. These challenges contribute to representativeness errors, affecting the validation of satellite-derived solar radiation products, especially at finer spatial and temporal scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for the variability in representativeness errors across different timescales and spatial resolutions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in representativeness errors across different timescales and spatial resolutions is due to the inherent differences in spatial scales between point-scale measurements and grid-level products, as well as dynamic atmospheric conditions. Errors are more pronounced for instantaneous products and shorter timescales, while longer timescales see reduced impacts of these errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from the reliance on high temporal resolution data, like half-hourly recordings, for the validation of radiation products in river basin studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Relying on high temporal resolution data, such as half-hourly recordings, for validation of radiation products can lead to more precise assessments of representativeness errors, particularly for instantaneous products. This approach helps in identifying errors attributable to differing spatial and temporal scales, ultimately contributing to more accurate validations. However, it may also highlight significant representativeness errors for grid-level products, necessitating careful consideration in validation approaches.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of producing surface PAR, solar radiation, and net radiation products with varying temporal resolutions in a dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to monitor surface radiation budget accurately over large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage using satellite remote sensing techniques, capturing dynamic changes such as cloud modulation that affect solar radiation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to address representativeness errors when validating remote sensing products with ground-based measurements?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Representativeness errors are crucial to address because they significantly influence the validation results, especially due to differing spatial scales between point-scale surface measurements and grid-level satellite products, which can lead to large differences in measurement and product data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of employing a surface flux-observation matrix for data collection in the Heihe river basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of a surface flux-observation matrix aims to provide comprehensive surface observation data, crucial for studying representativeness errors and validating satellite-derived solar radiation data, by covering a specific spatial area with multiple measurement systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in calculating the net radiation (NR) using satellite data and surface observations in the Heihe river basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: NR is calculated by analyzing the relationship between surface net shortwave radiation and net radiation. This involves combining data from geostationary meteorological satellites and MODIS products, using look-up tables for direct inversion.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable the accurate capture of spatial distributions and dynamic changes of clouds using satellite remote sensing?
Enablement.Answer: The satellite remote sensing technique offers large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage, which allows it to accurately capture the spatial distributions and dynamic changes of clouds. This method is considered superior to other approaches, such as discrete surface observation or reanalysis modeled products, in monitoring surface solar radiation.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of a surface flux-observation matrix enhance the understanding of representativeness errors in surface radiation measurements?
Enablement.Answer: The surface flux-observation matrix from HiWATER, which includes eddy covariance systems and automatic meteorological stations, enhances the understanding of representativeness errors by providing a comprehensive dataset. This matrix allows for the investigation of the errors associated with point-scale measurements and their relation to grid-level surrounding areas, contributing to the analysis of spatial scales and atmospheric conditions.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or corrections are necessary to ensure the reliability of continuous surface radiation measurements?
Enablement.Answer: To ensure the reliability of continuous surface radiation measurements, several corrections need to be applied, including thermal offset correction, calibration correction, leveling correction, and correction for soiling error. Continuous supervision is required, with spirit levels and glass domes of radiometers checked regularly to prevent instrument tilting and sensor soiling.

Expectation.Question: Why might the representativeness errors of surface measurements be significant in the validation of radiation products in remote sensing?
Expectation.Answer: Representativeness errors are significant due to the inherent differing spatial scales between point-scale ground-based measurements and grid-level satellite products. These errors fluctuate strongly depending on the time and space scales of remote sensing products and instant atmospheric conditions, leading to large differences between measurements and products.

Expectation.Question: Why are high-resolution spatio-temporal data crucial for accurately capturing solar radiation dynamics over the Heihe river basin?
Expectation.Answer: High-resolution spatio-temporal data are crucial because they allow for precise estimation of spatial distributions and dynamic changes of cloud, which are superior modulators of surface solar radiation. Satellite remote sensing provides large and continuous coverage needed to accurately capture these dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using satellite remote sensing techniques for capturing dynamic changes in cloud cover in comparison to other data collection methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques are considered highly effective for capturing dynamic changes in cloud cover due to their large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage. These techniques are superior to discrete surface observations or reanalysis modeled products because they can accurately capture spatial distributions and dynamic changes. This advantage is crucial, as cloud cover is a key modulator of surface solar radiation (SSR).

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the biggest challenges in ensuring the accuracy of net radiation (NR) calculations using satellite data?
Judgmental.Answer: One of the biggest challenges in ensuring the accuracy of net radiation (NR) calculations using satellite data lies in the representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based measurements. These errors are influenced by differing spatial scales and atmospheric conditions at the time of measurement. Additionally, challenges arise from the poor representativeness of surface sites, significantly contributing to discrepancies between measurements and satellite products.

Judgmental.Question: What considerations should be taken into account when integrating surface observation data with satellite products for radiation budget monitoring?
Judgmental.Answer: When integrating surface observation data with satellite products for radiation budget monitoring, it is important to consider the representativeness error of point-scale measurements relative to grid-level surroundings. This includes managing detailed errors from point to kilometer scales and macroscopic errors from kilometer to grid scales. Ensuring continuous supervision and correction of measurements, such as calibration and soiling errors, is also essential to maintain data integrity. Representativeness errors must be accounted for, especially on shorter timescales, as they significantly affect validation results.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how remote sensing techniques can effectively capture the spatial distributions and dynamic changes of cloud for solar radiation measurement.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing techniques, particularly using satellite data, are advantageous because they provide large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage. This allows accurate capture of cloud distributions and changes, which are crucial for modulating surface solar radiation (SSR). Satellite data can estimate SSR by integrating information from both geostationary and polar-orbiting satellites.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in ensuring the representativeness of point-scale ground-based measurements compared to satellite data for solar radiation studies.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in ensuring representativeness stem from the inherent differences in spatial scales between point-scale ground measurements and satellite data. Representativeness errors can fluctuate widely based on time, space scales, and atmospheric conditions. These errors significantly contribute to discrepancies between measurements and satellite products, raising questions about the suitability of using direct validation approaches.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges involved in data collection methods for surface solar radiation using remote sensing techniques and propose potential solutions to mitigate these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in data collection for surface solar radiation (SSR) using remote sensing include the representativeness error of surface measurements, which arises due to differing spatial scales between point-scale ground-based measurements and grid-level remote sensing products. This error is contingent on time, space scales, and atmospheric conditions. The poor representativeness of surface sites significantly contributes to large differences between measurements and products. Solutions to mitigate these challenges include ensuring continuous supervision during measurements, applying corrections such as thermal offset and calibration corrections, and utilizing a high temporal resolution for surface measurements, such as a 30-minute cycle, to improve validation accuracy for instantaneous products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and evaluate a data collection method used to capture the dynamic changes of cloud cover in relation to surface solar radiation products.
Request/Directive.Answer: A data collection method used to capture the dynamic changes of cloud cover in relation to SSR involves satellite remote sensing techniques, which provide large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage. This method accurately captures the spatial distributions and dynamic changes of clouds, which are superior modulators of SSR. By integrating products from geostationary meteorological satellites and MODIS, researchers can directly retrieve SSR data, allowing for a detailed analysis of cloud impact on radiation budget estimation. The method's evaluation indicates that it is mature and effective for generating SSR products, though it must account for representativeness errors in validation processes.
